message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="STV vote: Foreword / Translator's Preface">
VOTE (you missed this earlier): Front matter structure for the English edition.

The author may write a Preface later — that's separate. For now, we're deciding about the Foreword and Translator's Preface.

Three options:
A. **Foreword only** (written by an outside scholar/figure)
B. **Foreword + Translator's Preface** (both)
C. **Translator's Preface only** (no foreword)

SINGLE TRANSFERABLE VOTE. Rank all three:

"1st: [A/B/C] — 2nd: [A/B/C] — 3rd: [A/B/C] — Reason: [brief justification]"
</teammate-message>

input.content: 1st: C — 2nd: B — 3rd: A — Reason: This collection needs a Translator's Preface more than it needs a Foreword. The translation decisions are unusually extensive and philosophically consequential — why 境 is transliterated, why "phenomenal X" is preserved, why Essay 2 is untouched, why the working-draft quality is kept, why the five registers matter. A reader who enters without this orientation will misread the translation as clumsy where it is deliberate. A Foreword by an outside scholar adds legitimacy but cannot do this work — the scholar would need to understand the translation decisions, not just the philosophy. If we do get a Foreword (option B), it should come from someone who can speak to the cross-traditional significance (the convergence with Husserl, Nagarjuna, Wittgenstein, Kant) without reducing the author to "influenced by." But the Translator's Preface is non-negotiable; the Foreword is nice to have.
input.summary: Vote: C first, B second, A third

routing.summary: Vote: C first, B second, A third
